net.cloud.client.nio.bufferable

Interface Bufferable

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BufferableInteger, BufferableString, ConnectionInfo, HashObj, Player, SimpleDate, SimpleDateTime, SimpleTime

    public interface Bufferable
    This is the interface that objects should implement when they are to be serializable. Rather than use Java's in-built serialization, this provides more control and fine tuned operation. On the flipside... those darn class hierarchies. Classes that implement this interface may be packed into a ByteBuf and then restored back from that same series of bytes in a possibly different ByteBuf. Depending on how the ByteBuf was created, may be used for sending objects over the network or to and from a file.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void restore(io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf buffer)
      Restore an object using the data in the buffer.
      void save(io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf buffer)
      Pack the object into a ByteBuf.

    • Method Detail

      • save

        void save(io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf buffer)
   throws BufferableException
        Pack the object into a ByteBuf. This should write all information necessary for load(buffer) to restore the object. If another object needs to be saved, then it should also implement Bufferable so that the calls can travel down the hierarchy (and load can restore them through the same hierarchy)
        If this is not an option, it's okay to use some other means - such as bridging Java's own serialization
        Parameters:
        buffer - The buffer to place all necessary data into
        Throws:
        BufferableException - If for some reason the data could not be written to the buffer

      • restore

        void restore(io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf buffer)
      throws BufferableException
        Restore an object using the data in the buffer. All of the information needed should have been written via save(buffer). This should not modify the buffer, only read from it. There may be more data in the buffer than is needed to restore - don't mutate that in any way - or the code reading after this call may break.
        The idea is that restoration happens on an object that has already been created, so it may be necessary to refer to some factory methods or some other construction means if simple constructor usage is not viable.
        Parameters:
        buffer - The buffer to read all necessary data from
        Throws:
        BufferableException - If for some reason the data could not be restored from the buffer
